byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and RICHARD FAUSSET

abstract: Charleston, SC, massacre and ensuing push to take down Confederate flag have cast into relief tensions between Old South and new; region has gone through startling economic and social shifts, but old truths such as power of church, persistent poverty and racial divides remain; willingness of conservative southern politicians to join push to remove flag is nonetheless a remarkable milestone of change.
lead_paragraph: The massacre at a church in Charleston, S.C., this month casts the tensions between the Old South and the New into sharp relief.

headline.main: Straddling Old and New, a South Where ‘a Flag Is Not Worth a Job’
headline.print_headline: Southern Customs Yield to a New Age: ‘A Flag Is Not Worth a Job’
